episodes.title: JAPAN: RELIGIOUS CULT COMPOUND BECOMES TOURIST ATTRACTION
episodes.description:
(21 May 1995) Japanese/Nat

Villagers living near the Mount Fuji compound of the Aum doomsday cult want the  government to disband the sect and confiscate its land.

Cult guru Shoko Asahara - who is believed to have masterminded the nerve gas attacks  on the Tokyo subway - was arrested last week at the sect headquarters by the village of  Kamikuishiki.

Since the nerve gas attacks the village has been thrust into the media spotlight but  locals want life to return to normal and the remaining Aum followers out.

Mount Fuji -- it's one of Japan's main tourist attractions.

Scores of city dwellers leave Tokyo and head out near its white peaks for weekends of  peace and quiet - and to pursue their favourite sports.

But these paragliders also have the perfect bird's eye view of the Aum cult compounds  which lie in the shadow of Mount Fuji.

Sect leader Shoko Asahara reckoned he would be able to free fly within three years,  claiming he could already levitate.

But now he's grounded in police custody - and likely to face charges of murder and  attempted murder for the nerve gas attack last March.

Since March there has not been much peace or quiet in Kamikuishiki.

Police and an army of reporters, photographers and cameramen descended on the  farming village near Asahara's headquarters - plus hundreds of sightseers turned up for  a look.

The local supermarket has never been so busy with sales doubling in the last two  months.

Manager Motoaki Tsunoda has been rushed off his feet - but he doesn't expect things to  slow down for a while.

SOUNDBITE: (Japanese)
"The boom will continue until the end of this year whether I like it or not because the  Japanese are really curious, they want to see something weird. It is a little bit rude to  my customers but they want to see some strange and terrible things."
SUPER CAPTION: Motoaki Tsunoda, Store Manager

Locals can't wait for life to get back to normal - they say their village has become  famous for the wrong reasons.

SOUNDBITE: (Japanese)
"Because of the incident, Kamikuishiki has become really famous but I want it to be  popular because of its products not because of its cult compound."
SUPER CAPTION: Kazuya Tamura, Local

Dairy farming is how most of the locals earn their living.

But the activities of the cult have encroached more and more on people's lives to the  extent that a local anti-Aum committee was formed.

Signs in the area spell out the villagers' view of the cult.

New signs put up since Tuesday say 'Aum tell the truth' - replacing the old signs telling  the sect they were not welcome in the area.

Locals are adamant - they want the cult out.

SOUNDBITE: (Japanese)
"I really want everybody to leave here and maybe we can confiscate their land. Maybe  the local or national government could purchase the cults land and use it to build a new  factory."
SUPER CAPTION: Akiteru Watanabe, Farmer

SOUNDBITE: (Japanese)
"The entire withdrawal (of Aum followers) is what I really want but some of the members  have donated their houses and land to the cult so they have nowhere to go. This is not  just an issue for us but also for the country as a whole."
SUPER CAPTION: Seiichi Takeuchi, Local Anti-Aum Organiser

With Asahara behind bars, the future of the cult is unclear. Japanese authorities are  reportedly considering forcing it to disband.

episodes.description:
(23 Mar 1995) T/I:   10:27:57    10:06:13

Japanese police stormed more buildings used by the religious sect
Aum Shinri Kyo on Thursday (23/3) as the hunt continued for the
perpetrators of Monday's murderous nerve gas attacks in the Tokyo
subway. About 1,000 officers wearing gas masks and carrying caged
canaries for gas detection entered the sect's 11-building complex
in the village of Kamiku-Isshiki at the foot of Mount Fuji. Military poison-gas specialists investigated and neutralized chemicals found in a car owned by a member of the cult.  Police also confiscated what appears to be more chemicals from the sect's headquarters.

in Kobe one week before and we built factories in which we
do research.. I did the scientific part of AUM"

episodes.title: THAILAND: 2ND ALLEGED MEMBER OF AUM SHINRI KYO CULT ARRESTED
episodes.description:
(24 Feb 1996) English/Nat

Thai police have arrested a second man suspected of being linked to  a Japanese  doomsday religious cult accused of carrying out the fatal nerve gas attack on a Tokyo  subway last year.

The latest arrest in Bangkok comes less than a week before a major Asia-Europe  summit meeting in Thailand.

Police - in a crackdown on security before the summit - suspect the alleged Aum Shinri  Kyo cult member of plotting terrorists acts during the March 1-2 meeting of leaders from  25 Asian and European countries.

Thai police arrested Thursday 31-year-old Hiroyuki Shiyama who they suspect  Japanese cult, Aum Shinir Kyo.

On his arrest at a guest house in Bangkok they also found a small quantity of  marijuana in his possession.

The Japanese religious doomsday cult has been accused of carrying out the fatal nerve  gas attack on a Tokyo subway last year, killing 12 people and affecting 5,500 others.

Police say Shiyama is an associate of 51-year-old Keijiro Ota who was arrested a few  days earlier in Thailand.

Ota is allegedly not only a cult member but an assistant to Aum's leader.

Authorities suspect that the Japanese man was planning to carry out terrorist acts next  week at the Asia-Europe summit in Thailand.

The arrests come as Thai police are toughening up security measures ahead of the  summit on March 1-2 which will be attended by leaders from 10 Asian and 25 European  countries.

SOUNDBITE: 
"We try to prevent all of this not to happen before or during the summit."
SUPER CAPTION: Maj. Gen. Vera Pithakphol, Deputy Commissioner of Thai  Immigration Police

Japanese embassy officials, who had requested Ota's arrest on an extortion charge,  have said the arrested man's links with the cult are not clear.

But they thanked the police for their swift work.  

SOUNDBITE:
"I came to say thank you for the co-operation of Thai police authorities to apprehend a  person that Japanese authorities have been trying to arrest."
SUPER CAPTION:  Yoshikawa Motohide, Japanese Embassy spokesman

Police found a forged international press pass in Shiyama's hotel - a pass which would  have enabled him to get close to the leaders at next week's summit.

Although there are fears of a terrorist cell planted in the country ahead of the meeting,  Thai authorities say there is still no evidence of a terrorist plot - other than that Shiyama  is thought by police to be working for Ota.

SOUNDBITE:
"He is one of the members working for Ota. Ota is their leader and this one is one of his  men. But in importance of the people, Mr Ota is higher."
SUPER CAPTION: Police Maj Gen. Vera Pithakphol

When the seven ASEAN leaders met in Bangkok a couple of  months ago security was  notably laid back. 

Officers outside the conference fell asleep.

Now Thai authorities are eager to reassure everyone that the 25 leaders will be securely  protected by 5,000 specially trained officers mobilised for the meeting.

Police say they are working closely with INTERPOL to keep any more suspected  terrorists out of the country.

episodes.title: RR7912B GUYANA/MEXICO:FILMING THE JONESTOWN MASSACRE
episodes.description:
(21 Mar 1979) RR7912B GUYANA/MEXICO:FILMING THE JONESTOWN MASSACRE

In November 1978, the world was shocked when 1000
people died in an orgy of suicide and murder at the
camp of cult leader Jim Jones in Guyana.  Only 15 people
survived what Jones called "the white night".  Based on
their accounts of the bizarre circumstances leading up to
the suicide ceremony, a film is now being made in
Mexico.  The director, Rene Cardona Jr., has made his
reputation on disaster movies but is this a subject that
should be shown to cinema audiences at all?

episodes.title: USA: SAN DIEGO: OFFICIALS RULE OUT CRIMINAL CHARGES IN MASS SUICIDE
episodes.description:
(1 Apr 1997) English/Nat

Investigators in San Diego say all the evidence points to suicide for 39 members of the  Heaven's Gate cult.

They believe there are no other members of the cult beyond the 39 who killed  themselves last week at a mansion near San Diego.

And officials say they're ruling out criminal charges as the probe into the incident winds  down. 

Officials began moving the white body bags containing the remains of cult members  from a refrigerator truck at the San Diego County medical examiner's office on Monday.

They were placed in unmarked vans which then carried the corpses off to mortuaries.  Eleven bodies had been transferred by midday.

Officials say relatives had been located for all but two of the 39 victims.

Names and other details about the Heaven's Gate cult members were released in the  hope relatives could be found. 

San Diego police investigators say they're confident there are no other active members  of the cult beyond the 39 who took their own lives last Wednesday.

And with their probe of the case already winding down, San Diego officials are not  altering the conclusion that it was anything other than mass suicide. 

SOUNDBITE:
"The video tape discovered and observed, the information obtained from sources all  indicate that this was a voluntary situation. They ingested the drugs on their own, they  may or may not have been influenced, but we'll never know that. But at this stage this is  considered a mass suicide investigation."
SUPER CAPTION: Lt. Jerry Lipscomb, San Diego County Sheriff's department

Investigators were still trying to determine the source of the drug phenobarbital used in  the suicide, but Lipscomb said he did not think that would lead to charges.

SOUNDBITE:
"We're not going to charge anyone with anything, and who would we charge. The drugs  could be obtained legally. So there's no charges going to be persued by us in any  case."
SUPER CAPTION: Lt. Jerry Lipscomb, San Diego County Sheriff's department

San Diego County Medical Examiner Brian Blackbourne said eight male victims of the  cult had been castrated, including cult leader Marshall Applewhite. 

He also said the bodies were being tested for the H-I-V aids virus, but only because of  interest by relatives. But he said none of the victims had a terminal illness.

Members of the nomadic group, which made its living working on Internet web sites,  were found dead last Wednesday in a rented mansion in exclusive Rancho Santa Fe.

episodes.title: USA: GARLAND: TAIWANESE CULT GROUP PRESS CONFERENCE
episodes.description:
(23 Dec 1997) Mandarin/Nat

More than 20 Taiwanese families from a cult believed to be "God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Foundation" have arrived in Dallas because they believe God will appear in Garland, Texas, on March 31st.

Taiwanese officials fear they plan a Heaven's Gate-style mass suicide. 

But on Tuesday, members of the group held a news conference and dropped any reference to space stuff and simply called themselves the "True Way" church.

A religious group that's waiting for God to appear in Garland, a Texas suburb, wanted to make one thing perfectly clear to the media on Tuesday. 

Following intense speculation about their group and fears among officials that they may be about to carry out a mass suicide a press conference was called.

Spokesmen for the group said they were not like the "Heaven's Gate" cult and had no plans to commit suicide they told the gathered media.

But they did enlarge a little on what their group believed in.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"The child with the hat is the reincarnation of Jesus Christ's body, and the child without the hat is the reincarnation of Buddha.  And there is a legend, which is not stated in history or in any Buddhist scripture, but actually Buddha was poisoned, and his body was reincarnated into the child. "
SUPER CAPTION: Hon Ming Chen, Church Leader

More than 150 members of the group moved from Taipei to Garland in the middle of the year.

They were originally identified as the "God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Foundation." 

But at a news conference today they did not comment about specific beliefs involving U-F-O's and simply called themselves the "True Way" church.

The group leaders believe God will take over the body of their church leader, Hong-Ming Chen, on March 31st. 

His followers said Chen will then get three powers. He'll be able to clone himself, walk through walls and speak every language.

Chen himself explained some more about the church at the press conference.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"Two-thousand years ago, I was the father of Jesus Christ.  Two thousand and five hundred years ago, Jesus Christ was my son.  That is why I am so sad about history, and according to the revelation of God, God can appear in a human body, but he comes not to judge people, not to make the final judgement, but to save people.  Most parts in the Bible are not the true words of god.  They are the revelations of devils and demons."
SUPER CAPTION: Hon Ming Chen, Church Leader

Church members also predicted God will make a T-V announcement on March 25th -- to be seen only on "Channel 18" in the U-S.

If March comes and goes without the Almighty's appearance, they'll say they'll just pack up and return home.

But for the mean time the group members will spend the next couple of months patiently waiting for God to arrive in Garland.

episodes.title: USA-Bodies of Heaven's Gate cult members released
USA: TAIWANESE CULT DISAPPOINTED AT GOD'S FAILURE TO APPEAR ON TV
episodes.description:
(25 Mar 1998) Mandarin/Eng/Nat

A Taiwanese religious group in Texas was left disappointed on  Wednesday after God didn't appear on television as had been predicted by their leader..

Chen Heng-ming admitted that in the light of God's failure to appear on cable TV also meant his prediction that he was returning to earth on March 31 was nonsense.

Chen said his followers were free to go but he would continue in the Dallas suburb to "continue studying and researching".

Well before midnight on Tuesday, TV crews from around the world had set up camp around the house of the Chen Heng-ming, a Taiwanese religious leader in Garland, Texas.

Chen had predicted that God would appear across the United States on Channel 18 at a minute past midnight. 

The event, he said, would presage His return to earth next week on march 31, ushering in a new era for the human race.

In Garland, Channel 18 offers religious-oriented programming, in nearby Dallas, it is a
home-shopping channel.

Implied in the media and police attention is the notion that church members might take drastic or unexpected action if God does not appear. 

But Chen and his followers insisted they had no plans to harm themselves, adding that suicide would violate God's principles.

Members of  God's Salvation Church, began arriving at the Dallas suburb at around 8 p-m, in plenty of time for the main event.

Despite their leader's assurances however, the group's spokesman admitted the possibility that God might not make His appearance.

SOUNDBITE:
We have the only true - we have the only faith in God's power. If the plan is postponed or changed we have the belief that God has some better plan in order to save more people from the great revelation in 1999.
SUPER CAPTION: Richard Liu, Spokesperson

Non-cultists in this tree-lined Dallas suburb have been bemused by the group's predictions.

Neighbours Bruce and Shirley Fain tuned into Channel 18 - just in case.

But, as they suspected, God failed to manifest.

SOUNDBITE:
Well, it's five minutes after twelve right now and Heng-ming Chen's not on there yet. and according to his own philosophy and preachings that we've heard he's a phoney.
SUPER CAPTION: Bruce Fain, Neighbour

Chen, in a news conference held on his front lawn, stood before more than 100 reporters and neighbours and admitted he had got it wrong.

God's failure to appear on TV meant, he said, that his predictions of His return to earth on March 31 could be treated as nonsense.

But he said his faith remained unbowed. 

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"First of all, I hope that everybody can still have the true belief in God, in the existence of God, even though the image doesn't show on the television, I don't have any reason to doubt the existence of God, the supreme being in this universe."
SUPER CAPTION: Chen Heng-ming, Church leader

Too few people are aware of God's word, he said, and he expressed hope that the mass media attention could help change that.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"As a matter of truth, the attention that the mass media has given to us couldn't be done by human efforts and we do believe that only a holy arrangement could make it so that so much attention could be attracted to the gospel we are preaching."
SUPER CAPTION: Chen Heng-ming, Church leader

The group's prophecies come almost exactly a year after the Heaven's Gate sect committed mass suicide in Rancho Santa Fe, California. 

Texas is particularly sensitive to unusual religious movements.


sounds like "God's Land".

episodes.title: PERU: HARE KRISHNA RELIGION RECRUITING LARGE FOLLOWING
episodes.description:
(18 Jul 1998) Spanish/Nat

The Hare Krishna religion has been recruiting a large following in Peru.

There are more than 18-thousand followers in Lima alone, and hundreds of others throughout the country.

The Hare Krishnas have opened several restaurants and two plants making vegetarian products.

Every day, just before 4-30 in the morning, scores of Hare Krishna faithful gather at this temple in Chosica to practice their faith.

The 'Temple of Understanding' is the largest of its kind in Peru.

It was founded in 1990 by those who imported the Hare Krishna religion into the country in 1976.

The average day of a Hare Krishna follower begins with a series of chants and dances - known as Aratiks - just before dawn.

The Aratiks can be performed up to four times during the day, and during these ceremonies the leaders of the congregation change the clothes on the statues of their deities.

There are some 18-thousand Hare Krishnas in Lima alone, and scores of others throughout Peru.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"It's not a sectarian or fanatic cult. It's open to everyone and we have the willingness to share our experiences with people from all kinds of cults, regardless of race, culture, social and economic status."
SUPER CAPTION: Yaeshi Krishna Das, Member of Hare Krishna congregation

The faithful go to the temple to find an answer to their existential questions and to pay homage to God, who they call Krishna.

Most of the day is spent chanting, dancing and reflecting.

For many followers, the religion has dramatically changed their lives.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"Through God's pity, I realised that my life was wrong, and through a real process I was able to change my life. I stopped eating meat, having illegal sex and getting drunk overnight. I started living with people who enjoyed purity, and that pleased me a lot."
SUPER CAPTION: Yaeshi Krishna Das, Member of Hare Krishna congregation

The Hare Krishnas in Peru are sticking to vegetarianism.

They run several restaurants and two plants that make vegetarian products.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"People who eat, feed goodness. Vegetables develop goodness and people can understand their souls, understand God and transcend. Other people cannot, therefore, vegetarianism is the first step."
SUPER CAPTION: Yaeshi Krishna Das, Member of Hare Krishna congregation

During their daily ceremony, the Krishnas offer food to their deities and pay homage to their founder, Prabhupada.

Then they eat their meals which are free of meat and alcohol.

Various generations of Hare Krishnas gather at the temples, which are proliferating throughout Peru's largest cities.

But the Krishnas say numbers are not important, and that they would be happy with only two members, as long as they're true to their faith.

episodes.title: USA: JONESTOWN GUYANA MASSACRE 20 YEARS ON (4)
episodes.description:
(18 Nov 1998) English/Nat

A group of survivors of the Jonestown deaths marked the twentieth anniversary on Tuesday night with a three-hour prayer vigil.

Survivors of the tragedy in which 900 people died, remembered their own narrow escapes from the Jonestown sect's commune and counted their blessings to be alive.

Perhaps the most famous survivor, Deborah Layton - who alerted the world that people were held against their will - is touring the U-S with a new book about the cult.

In a church in San Francisco, the survivors' thank their lucky stars they are alive.

Their stories reflect the luck and courage of their escape.

One survivor helped a small group escape the commune by telling guards he had organised a picnic.

Just by chance, he escaped the tragedy that took place in the People's Temple in Jonestown in the ex-British colony of Guyana.

The adopted son of Jim Jones, Jim Jones Jr, escaped death because he and his brother had gone into town to see a basketball game.

The younger Jones said it was God who made it possible for him to hug one of the women he had pulled to safety.

He said he attended the service to heal old wounds.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"I think, one, is forgiveness, forgiveness for myself for surviving. I think, two, is forgiveness for the failures of Rev Jim Jones, he is not God, he is only a man. And when many people placed him in a God-like role he then believed it. And that's the tragedy of Jonestown."
SUPER CAPTION: (English) Jim Jones, Jr., Adopted son of Jim Jones

One of Jonestown's most famous survivors is marking the anniversary by touring with a new book about her experience.

Deborah Layton joined Jim Jones and his People's Temple after graduating from boarding school at the age of 17.

After more than seven years in the group, Layton followed Jones to Guyana ... and it was there that she began to realise this leader was terribly dangerous.

In her recently released autobiography, "Seductive Poison," Layton describes the so-called "white nights," or weekly suicide drills.

She recalled what happened to those who refused to join in.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"A mother, for example, who would say, 'No, I don't want to kill my child, I wont do that', she as an example to us would be taken from that child and drugged and kept in the medical unit, comatose.  So your choices were, you follow, you act like your part of the team and somehow you hope you can figure a way out.  Those people, you know, in the very end, what seems comforting to people to say these people committed suicide, they didn't, they were murdered, they died not wanting, they were murdered by Jim Jones."
SUPER CAPTION: Deborah Layton, Jonestown Survivor

Layton managed to escape the guarded compound, leaving her brother and dying mother behind.

She says in Jonestown, the sect's leader became increasingly angry and paranoid following a string of negative press reports.

And she knew his talk of a mass suicide would soon become a reality.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"His paranoia just grew and became just a malignant tumour upon him and he could have let those people live but he wanted to make a point and a statement.  All those good people who joined for the most wonderful reasons, who wanted to be part of something bigger than themselves where used as fodder in the end, so that he could make his point, don't anyone mess with me."
SUPER CAPTION: Deborah Layton, Jonestown Survivor

Among the dead were more than 270 children.

Armed guards shot anyone who refused.

Even two decades later, the scars from the tragedy are thick and deep.

episodes.title: MEXICO: CULT ACCUSED OF PREPARING FOR MASS SUICIDE
episodes.description:
(3 Aug 1999) Spanish/Japanese/Nat

A small town in Mexico called the New Jerusalem has become home to an apocalyptic cult of over two hundred residents who believe the world will end before the year two thousand.

They call themselves the 'spiritual order' and maintain that their incessant prayer is in preparation for their 'long journey' after the end of the world.

Disillusioned members accuse the group of being religious fanatics heading towards mass suicide.

The order prays almost 24 hours a-day, believing that their souls will be saved as they embark on what they say will be their long journey after the apocalypse.

Members that have been expelled from the group accuse the Christian fundamentalist spiritual order of being religious fanatics preparing for a ritualistic mass suicide before the millennium.

Neither the church authorities nor government officials have any idea about the group's religious origins or motivations.

Since the secret cult was established in Mexico in 1973 no one has managed to enter the compound to obtain an interview with their leader Papa Nabor.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"Well, I don't know really. I feel they are all being fooled. Since we arrived here they have been saying that the world is going to end and look... it is still here. It is something that only God can know."
SUPER CAPTION: Isabel Diaz, Former Cult member

The members of the cult come from all walks of life and are united by their vows of poverty.

They agree to a severe daily ritualistic practice that, if broken, brings immediate expulsion.

They are also bound by rules that require a certain amount of work on behalf of the church and a vow to refrain from intoxicants and physical contact.

Pregnancy is also forbidden.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"Like everything wholesome that is bathing in the grace of God. That is what indicates to another life. Not life of this earth but the promised life in heaven."
SUPER CAPTION: Papa Nabor, cult leader

Despite its secrecy, the sect has no walls surrounding the compound.

When police raided it looking for poisons to be used in a mass suicide they found nothing more than twenty five people dressed in white fervently praying.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"They say in the compound that mass practised out here is meaningless. That it only means something in there. That I do not understand."
SUPER CAPTION: Antolina Martinez Rubio, expelled cult member

Whatever the rumours surrounding the cult, the only evidence against them is that they are profoundly secretive.

And the secrecy and rumours heightens the fear that local residents have towards the group which constantly tells them that the world will end any day soon and the wrath of God will befall them.

episodes.title: USA: WASHINGTON: FALUN GONG SECT PROTEST
episodes.description:
(1 Oct 1999) English/Nat 

In Washington DC, members of the Falun Gong sect carried out a group meditation session outside the Chinese embassy on Friday as a protest marking the 50th anniversary of the founding of communist China.

China banned the sect in July, accusing it of spreading superstition and trying to replace the Communist government.

The Falun Gong members tried to deliver a letter of peace to the Chinese Embassy but without success.

SOUNDBITE (English) 
Some people are treated very badly, some people because of this 50th anniversary, government feel (that) the practitioners are a threat. They just arbitrarily detained a lot of people to make sure that they don't go to Beijing and disturb this. 
SUPERCAPTION: Dana Chang, Falun Gong Practitioner  

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"They say today, they do not work but you see the door is opened, somebody is inside, Because they saw me come here, they just close the door, I think this is ridiculous because I am a Chinese citizen. Today is the celebration of the Chinese government for 50 years. I think I have a right and also I'm proud to be here and to deliver what I thought . Many practitioners hope but they just close the door, they don't want to hear anything from us. Still members how peaceful behaviour asking the government to release those who were withheld against their will in mainland China. 
SUPERCAPTION:  Zhong Tang, Falun Gong member  

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"We are not against anything with the Chinese government, we just want to be very peacefully and nice people, we want them to release all the arrested practitioners, they are innocent. "
SUPERCAPTION:  Zhong Tang, Falun Gong member

episodes.title: ISRAEL: CHRISTIAN DOOMSDAY TRIAL LATEST
episodes.description:
(4 Jan 1999) English/Nat

Members of a Christian cult were brought to court in Israel on Monday for first  discussions on their arrest.  

Israeli police had arrested the 14 missing members of the cult - based in the U-S state  of Colorado - the day before.

Police say in doing so, they foiled a bloody plot the apocalyptic group hoped would  bring Christ's return.

Four of the American doomsday cult members have been brought before the court so  far ... the rest were ordered to be deported.

Israeli police have said the cult members planned to provoke a bloody shootout by  opening fire on police on the streets of Jerusalem.

Members of the group believed this catastrophic act would hasten the second coming of  Christ.

The attorney for Eric Malesic, one of the cult members arrested, says he is claiming  innocence. 

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"The suspect denies all the allegations of being involved in any illegal actions, and he  says it will all come in the trial."
SUPER CAPTION: Public defender Eran Avital, attorney for Eric Malesic

Malesic, like the other cult members, face deportation. 

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"He says the Israeli defence office will present in court some kind of tapes that he was  talking about committing suicide or harming any other people in Israel or any other  place in Israel. He say that these allegations are not true, they will never find any kind  of tape like that. They never taped him or his family like that and he never take part in  any illegal actions in Israel or abroad. 
SUPER CAPTION: Public defender Eran Avital, attorney for Eric Malesic

The cultists had been arrested on Sunday at two homes in suburban Jerusalem, by a  newly formed Israeli task force consisting of police, agents of the domestic Shin Bet  security service, and the Mossad spy agency.

The cult drama, three days into 1999 raised the curtain on what Israeli authorities fear  could be turbulence leading up to the turn of the millennium.

Tens of thousands of Christian pilgrims are expected to visit the Holy Land this year,  but officials worry the millennium also will draw deranged extremists seeking to live out
apocalyptic fantasies.

The police asked the court to continue with the arrest in order to complete the
investigation of three of them and to deport 11 others.

episodes.title: ISRAEL: 14 US DOOMSDAY CULT MEMBERS DEPORTED
episodes.description:
(9 Jan 1999) Natural Sound  

Fourteen members of an American doomsday cult are on their way home after being booted out of Israel.

Police took them to Ben Gurion airport on Friday and put them on the flight to Toronto - from there, they'll make a connection back to their Denver home. 

The members of the Concerned Christians are suspected of plotting attacks in Jerusalem, believing that would hasten the return of Jesus Christ. 

They deny doing anything wrong and no charges were filed - but Israel deported them nonetheless.

Four police cars and vans took the group, including six children, to Ben Gurion International Airport near the Israeli capital Tel Aviv.

Arriving at 2000 GMT at the airport, they were then to catch an Air Canada flight to Toronto, with a connection to Denver, Colorado.

Two cult members covered their heads with coats when they spotted T-V cameras at the airport's Shalom Gate. 

None responded to questions shouted out by reporters.

There is growing concern in Israel in the run up to the close of the millennium.

Israelis fear the Concerned Christians - as the group call themselves - are only a forerunner of hundreds of fanatics who will be drawn to Israel for what they expect to be the Second Coming of Christ.

Millennial researchers say such extremists could turn violent if their hopes are not met. 

Other scenarios speak of possible mass suicides at holy sites.

Israel's police have created a task force to try to grapple with the problem.

Arriving in Israel in September, the cult members had settled in two homes in the wooded suburbs of Mevasseret Zion and Moza and were eventually placed under police surveillance.

The homes were raided earlier this week and the 14 were detained. 

Three cult members were questioned by police about alleged plots to carry out acts of violence at Jerusalem's holy sites in an attempt to hasten the return of Jesus.

The cult members denied wrongdoing and no charges were filed, but they were deported anyway.

On Friday morning, two handcuffed members of the group had been brought by security agents back to the home in Mevasseret Zion to pick up their luggage. 

The bags were carried out by the agents.

After the convoy arrived at the airport, two policemen presented the cult members' passports to the Air Canada check-in counter. 

Police said security agents would accompany the group on the flight.

Earlier on Friday, at Jerusalem's Al Aqsa mosque, prayer leader Hayan al-Idrisi referred to the cult in his sermon to more than 250-thousand worshippers.

According to one scenario cited by millennium researchers, Christian extremists might try to damage Al Aqsa, Islam's third holiest shrine, to pave the way for rebuilding the Jewish Temple.

The rebuilding of the Temple is considered by some Christians a necessary step towards the return of Christ.

Al-Idrisi claimed the Denver group plotted to destroy Al Aqsa.

However, police never made such an accusation. 

An Israeli police source only said Al Aqsa is only one possible location for a violent act by Christian fanatics.

The Israeli lawyer who briefly represented three group members said he was never shown the alleged evidence against his clients.

He also said the three did not want to return home because they feared the United States would be destroyed soon.

episodes.title: ISRAEL: DOOMSDAY CULTS UPDATE
episodes.description:
(8 Jan 1999) English/Nat

Israel is to deport 14 alleged members of a U-S doomsday cult. 

The group was detained earlier this week on suspicion of plotting a violent incident in Jerusalem to bring about the Second Coming of Jesus as the millennium approaches.

They are expected to leave the country on Friday night.

The 14 cult members arrived in Israel in September, settling in two homes in the Jerusalem suburbs of Mevasseret Zion and Moza.

They eventually came under police surveillance.

Now they are packing their belongings as Israeli authorities prepare to deport them this weekend.

Earlier this week, police raided the two homes and detained the group, among them six children.

Deportation orders were issued against them all. 

This unidentified cult member arrived at the group's home on Friday  to pick up several
suitcases and duffel bags.

The man, who was handcuffed and accompanied by security agents, refused to answer reporters' questions. 

UPSOUND: (English)
Reporter: "Are you going to leave the country? No? Are you going to leave the country soon? Is it true that.."
Cult member: "I don't have anything to say at this point."
Reporter: "Have you requested to be moved to Greece, is that true?"

Three cult members, who were questioned by police earlier this week, have told their Israeli lawyer that they don't want to return home because they fear the U-S will be destroyed soon. 

They said they would prefer to go to Greece, but it was not clear whether Greece would accept them.

Earlier on Friday, police accompanied the oldest son of one of the cult members into one of the houses in Mevasseret Zion. 

The young man, who appeared to be in his late teens or early twenties was handcuffed when he emerged from the house after about an hour.

Police drove him away to an unknown destination.

Police suspected the cult members were planning a violent incident at one of Jerusalem's holy sites in the hope that it would result in the Second Coming of Christ as the new millennium approaches.

The group's leader, Monte Kim Miller, who is not in Israel, has said he would die in the streets of Jerusalem in December 1999 and be resurrected three days later.

There has been concern that cult members were planning a mass suicide.

Police said one possible location for a violent act by Christian fanatics was the Al
Aqsa Mosque compound, also known as the Temple Mount, a site sacred to Judaism and Islam.

According to millennium researchers, Christian extremists might try to damage Al Aqsa to pave the way for rebuilding the Jewish Temple, considered by some a necessary condition for the Second Coming.

episodes.title: UGANDA: KANUNGU: CULT SUICIDE FIRE LATEST
episodes.description:
(21 Mar 2000) English/Nat

Prisoners are being used to dig large common graves for hundreds of cult members believed to have committed suicide in Uganda on Friday.

Police say more than 330 sect members died in the church fire in Kanunga, near Uganda's capital.

Many of the victims were women and children.

Locals brave enough to visit the burned hulk of the former church hall faced a gruesome sight - the charred remains of Ugandan cult members who, it's believed, doused themselves with inflammable liquid and set themselves alight on Friday. 

Kanunga is 215 miles (350 kilometres) southwest of Uganda's capital of Kampala.

Police believe most of the victims here were women.

They have counted the bodies of 78 children, and put the total number of dead inside the church at 330.

Another five bodies were spotted through a hole in a nearby pit latrine.

The 10-year-old Christian sect, known as the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God, was founded by Cledonia Mwerinde, a former prostitute who had the chapel built on the grave of her father.

The sect had about 1,000 members in nine districts in Uganda and was legally registered as a non-governmental organisation.

SOUNDBITE: (Rukiga)
"I left this place because of the hard labour. Three times a week, we were prevented from eating and we were not allowed to have sex. We were also discouraged from speaking and we communicated using gestures."
SUPER CAPTION: Turyakira Ivan, Former Cult Member

On Monday, prisoners were used to dig a long trench - a common grave, and final resting place for the five main cult leaders and their hundreds of followers.

Later reports, however, suggest only two leaders' bodies had been positively identified - the manager of the sect's farm and "a priest."

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"The leader of this cult who was called Joseph Kibweteere, we don't know up to now where he is. Supposedly some of his family members are saying that he had come to his end and previously there were reports that he had gone to hospital for treatment so up to now we don't know where he is."
SUPER CAPTION:  Bakandema William, District Information Officer

As a bulldozer shovelled corpses into a trench, locals were left asking how this could happen and whether it could happen again. 

They fear Syncretic Christian religious sects are mushrooming across Africa as people become disillusioned with the inability of politicians to improve their lives.

episodes.title: UGANDA: DOOMSDAY CULT TRAGEDY: MEMORIAL
episodes.description:
(2 Apr 2000) English/Nat
TOKO MATERIAL 

Uganda's leaders called their people to prayers and mourning on Sunday in Kanunga, the hilltop base of the Christian doomsday sect involved in the deadliest cult tragedy in modern history.

Government and religious leaders from various denominations attended the memorial service in the southwestern village, where a March 17 blaze inside a sealed church burned hundreds of members to death.

Since then, mass graves at three other sect compounds have yielded hundreds more bodies, many stabbed and strangled.

Uganda's government said Sunday's service was meant to console the families and assure the nation that it would pursue those who orchestrated the deaths.

Before the service, the country's Vice President Speciosa Wandira Kazibwe visited the church site in the Kanunga cult compound and laid flowers at the graves of the dead.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"The relatives were murdered and the government is going to do all it can to put the leaders of this cult on the hook. However, whatever consolation (can) you give to people when they lose their relatives like this."
SUPER CAPTION: Speciosa Wandira Kazibwe, Vice President of Uganda

In the sect compound, a classroom blackboard bore the ominous words, 'Let us go and burn'.

This might have sufficed as a neat, if tragic, explanation for the fate of followers of a Christian fringe sect whose end-of-the-world prediction failed to come true.

If not for the bodies of six men found in the compound's latrine, the notion that a sect with hopes for the end of the world had immolated itself might have prevailed.   

But now the deaths are being treated as mass murder.

It's thought key cult leaders may have survived the slaughter, fleeing with belongings their followers surrendered in order to join the sect.

The 10-year-old Christian sect, known as the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God, became popular after it was joined by Cledonia Mwerinde, a former prostitute.

She sold her spiritual wares to the gullible and the searching, particularly among the ranks of disaffected Roman Catholics, and gained daunting power over nearly 1-thousand followers, many of who apparently later became her victims.   

Her ex-husband, Eric Mazima, said she deserved death or a prison sentence for what she had orchestrated.

SOUNDBITE (Bakiba) 
"I'll be very pleased, very interested to find her in prison, in custody or dead , because what she did does not please me at all"
SUPER CAPTION: Eric Mazima, Ex-husband of Cledonia Mwerinde

No sect member, past or present, has confirmed the common belief that the failure of the world to end on December 31 spurred members to demand belongings they had surrendered to Mwerinde to join the sect. 

In turn, the reasoning goes, that inspired an insurrection that was put down with murder.   
Events leading up to the March 17 conflagration in Kanungu suggest a well-conceived plan - "mass suicide" as an alibi to cover up murders of nearly 400 men, women and children that already had been committed over the previous two weeks. 

The memorial ceremony on Sunday was held at a football pitch in Kanungu and was attended by church leaders from all over the country, as well as the Vice President.

They had 924 deceased people to mourn, and it's still not clear how their deaths were orchestrated, all within a 50-mile (an 80-kilometer) radius among green hills and volcanic lakes in southwestern Uganda.

episodes.title: UGANDA: BUHUNGA: CULT SUICIDE MASS BURIAL
episodes.description:
(25 Mar 2000) English/Nat

A mound of dirt is the only memorial to 153 members of a doomsday Christian sect buried in a mass grave in Buhunga sub-county, Uganda.

The discovery of the bodies came nearly a week after more than 300 other members of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments were burned alive in Kanungu.

The gruesome discovery of another mass grave in Uganda, just a week after 300 members a doomsday Christian sect were burnt alive, has increased fears that similar graves may be found across the country.

On Wednesday, villagers discovered three mass graves, which were dug into the dirt floors of two small rooms of a building belonging to the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments, in Buhunga.

Last week 300 members of the same sect died in a fire in a makeshift church in Kanungu, 30 kilometres (20 miles) from Buhunga. 

The Ugandan authorities fear that more corpses have yet to be discovered across the East African nation.  

On Friday, police exhumed the bodies at Buhunga, examined them, and then reburied them in a single grave.

Ugandan Police said some of those buried in the mass grave at Buhunga appeared to have been strangled or hacked to death.

Henry Ndyambahika, a local council member, said that the bodies had been buried over a period of months - some bodies four months ago, some six weeks ago and some much more recently.

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"Some of them were hit on the head and others were tied with ropes. The others I think they died a natural death."
SUPER CAPTION: Naubhika Henry, Chairperson, Buhunga sub-county

Minister of Internal Affairs Edward Rugumayo said in the capital, Kampala, that police had been mobilized across the country to search buildings and land belonging to the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments.

But for the families of those who died here, nothing can bring their loved ones back.

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"My sister died here."
SUPER CAPTION: Kika Adivn, Victim's Sister

Ndyambahika said the sect members in Buhunga sold all their property a week before the Kanungu inferno, then went to Kanungu. 

A few hours after the people there burned to death, some of the sect members returned, burning down their own compound.

Since no one remained, authorities said they believed that someone responsible fled the area.

The exact number of deaths in the Kanungu fire remains unclear, as many of the corpses were reduced to ashes.

Kanungu is 345 kilometres (215 miles) southwest of Kampala. 

All those deaths are now being treated as murders.

At first, police had thought the adult victims in the church inferno were willing participants, and considered only the 78 children who died there as murder victims.

But after the second discovery, police began treating all the deaths as homicides.

episodes.title: USA: FALUN GONG CULT PROTEST IN WASHINGTON
episodes.description:
(21 Jul 2000) English/Nat
XFA 
Falun Gong members held a peaceful protest outside the Chinese embassy in the U-S capital, Washington, on Thursday.

The event marked the first anniversary of the Chinese government's crackdown on the group.

A spokesman for the Chinese embassy condemned the movement as a dangerous, mind-controlling cult. 

Founded eight years ago, Falun Gong attracted (M) millions of followers in China with its blend of slow-motion exercises, meditation and ideas drawn from Buddhism and Taoism. 

More than a hundred Falun Gong protesters stood vigil outside the Chinese Embassy in Washington D-C.

Falun Gong was founded eight years ago by a former government clerk Li Hongzhi.

His whereabouts are unknown, but the popularity of his movement has been in no doubt.

Falun Gong's blend of slow-motion exercises, meditation and religious philosophy has appealed to (M) millions within China. 

But its popularity was seen as a threat by the government there and Thursday represented the first anniversary of China's crackdown on the group. 

Falun Gong says 24 members of the movement were killed whilst in custody and thousands of others were arrested and detained. 

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"By doing the exercises, and increasing our mind-nature Xin-Xing, we are becoming a good person, and have a healthy body. And if a hundred million people are doing this, we are saving a lot of - tons of - money for the government. What's wrong with it? I think it's only good for the government, for the whole world for the whole society." 
SUPER CAPTION: Tian Lun, Falun Gong Practitioner

Although senior figures within Falun Gong say it's a purely spiritual movement with its roots in Buddhism, the Chinese government has branded it a cult and an illegal political movement.

The press counsellor at the Chinese Embassy in Washington, Zhang Yuanyuan, said Falun Gong supporters have joined with anti-Chinese forces, an action he believes belies their spiritual claims of truthfulness and compassion.

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"There are forces, this is no secret, forces in the world who sort of disapprove of some of China's policies, and the Falun Gong, apparently, is a handy tool for them to use." 
SUPER CAPTION: Zhang Yuanyuan, Press Counselor, Chinese Embassy

Zhang also said that more than 98 percent of the "old-time practitioners" have made a "clean break" with the group.

But when asked to explain how the government determined the statistic, he referred only to anecdotal evidence.

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"The Falun Gong has lost it's credibility, has lost it's base in China. But it is still quite a powerful force. It still has some following inside the country and around the world. So our struggle - we cannot rest assured - until we win complete victory against the Falun Gong."
SUPER CAPTION: Zhang Yuanyuan, Press Counselor, Chinese Embassy

Zhang repeated government accusations that the group cheats its followers and has caused hundreds to die by convincing them to refuse medical treatment. 

He said their leaders use them as "cannon fodder against the law of the land."

episodes.title: ROVING REPORT: RR0043/C  AFRICA: WITCHCRAFT
episodes.description:
(27 Oct 2000) Christianity is the fastest growing religion in eastern, sub-Saharan Africa, and one of the reasons for its success is its ability to subsume other cultures.  It's resulted in what some might see, as an unholy alliance between Christianity and the culture of the witchdoctor. Many Africans still see their more traditional spiritual leaders as a necessary aspect of life, and have no qualms about combining the two faiths. But in East Africa religion is being manifested in many guises; from the witchdoctor's healing to the mass suicide of a religious cult in Uganda.

episodes.title: latest on banned sect in China
episodes.description:
(19 Apr 2001) 

19 April 2001, Washington, D.C.
1. Wide view of Falun Gong display in front of Chinese embassy.
2. Close view of Falun Gong banner in front of embassy.
3. Close view of Chinese flag. 
4. Mid view of embassy display of anti-Falun Gong information.
5. Close view of embassy display with photos and text ("Over 1500 People Have Died of Practicing "Falun Gong").
6. Close view of embassy display with text and photos ("Disturbing Public Order").
7. Close view of embassy name plate. 
8. Mid view of press briefing by Chinese embassy spokesman.
9. Mid view of reporters at briefing.
10. SOUNDBITE: (English) Zhang Yuan Yuan,  Chinese embassy spokesman. "According to some Chinese commentators, the United States has always adopted a rather tough approach towards cult problems inside the United States, while following a different standard when it comes to cult problems in other countries, including China...like in the Falun Gong case."
11. Mid view of briefing.
12. Close view of reporter at briefing.
13. SOUNDBITE: (English) Zhang Yuan Yuan, Chinese embassy spokesman. "In three batches we have provided American law enforcement with many convincing arguments against Zhang Hongbao. So there should be no doubt that Zhang Hongbao has committed serious crimes against Chinese citizens. And...he should face justice in China.
14. Mid view of briefing.

STORYLINE:

Followers of China's Falun Gong movement are encamped outside the Chinese embassy in Washington D-C Thursday. 

They've erected protest banners in a courtyard near the entrance to the sprawling brick embassy building in downtown Washington. 

Followers have been speaking out this week in the U-S capital, protesting China's official crackdown on activities of those who practice Falun Gong in China.

Falun Gong supporters say the crackdown has been harsh and violent, and is a clear example of China's dismal record on human rights. 

But the embassy is putting out a different message on Falun Gong, just a few feet away from where Falun Gong supporters are protesting.

Just in front of the embassy, Chinese officials display what they view as the real truth behind Falun Gong, presenting what they say is evidence that Falun Gong is a dangerous cult.

Inside the embassy Thursday, a spokesman blasted recent efforts to have concerns about Falun Gong followers and possible human rights issues brought before the United Nations. 

That effort, says the spokesman, has U-S support and only serves to harm relations between Washington and Beijing on the issue of human rights.  

On a related issue, China is also demanding that the U-S return the leader of the banned Chinese meditation sect Zhong Gong.

The embassy spokesman says Chinese officials have ample evidence of sect leader Zhang Hongbao's involvement in crimes such as rape and murder.

The 47-year-old Zhang was jailed in Guam 13 months ago after fleeing China. 

He's now awaiting immigration hearings in the United States.

Zhang was released Tuesday by U-S immigration officials in Hawaii and plans to move to either Washington state or Los Angeles, according to his lawyer. 

Zhong Gong, the meditation group he founded in 1987, was outlawed following a crackdown on the better-known Falun Gong sect in 1999.

episodes.title: Banned sect broadcast on Chinese satellite
episodes.description:
(8 Jul 2002) 

Beijing, China - 8 July 2002
1. Mid shot of start of news conference
2. Cutaway of journalists
3. Wide shot of news conference
4. SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin) Liu Lihua, Director-General, Ministry of Information Industry, Radio Regulatory Department:
"We wish to sternly warn those Falun Gong elements who have ulterior motives to immediately stop these illegal acts of interfering with normal communications and we would like to call on the international community to jointly condemn this mean act and take concerted efforts and measures to put an end to these kind of illegal acts."
5. Wide shot of video recording being shown at briefing, shot zooms in
6. Cutaway of cameras
7. Journalists
8. SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin) Liu Lihua, Director-General, Ministry of Information Industry, Radio Regulatory Department:
"(Falun Gong leader) Li Hongzhi manipulated and directed an overseas based Falun Gong cult organisation in flagrant opposition to the relevant international conventions and basic norms governing civil communication and deliberately interfered with the satellite communication and radio broadcast. We strongly condemn this despicable act."
9. Wide shot of news conference

Hong Kong, Special Administrative Region, China - 1 July 2002
10. Wide shot of Falun Gong demonstration
11. Tilt down from face of Falun Gong practitioner to T-shirt reading: SOS
12. Falun Gong protester performing Falun Gong moves
13. Banner in English: "Rescue the Falun Gong Practitioners Persecuted in China"
14. SOUNDBITE: (English) Ken Hong Cheung, Falun Gong protestor:
"We want to call on the attention of the world and also the public that Falun Gong is persecuted in China. And we urge them to help us stop the persecution in China."
15. Wide shot of old man standing in front of banner in Chinese, reads: "The Great Way is good"
16. Close up on man's face as he performs Falun Gong exercises

STORYLINE:

The Chinese government on Monday denounced what it called video hacking by Falun Gong, saying the banned spiritual movement interrupted a peak-hour broadcast last month to air what they call propaganda.

Top broadcast officials condemned the June 23 incident, which they said affected transmissions of a channel the government beams via satellite to remote areas of China that have little access to outside news.

Liu Lihua, China's chief broadcast regulator, blamed overseas Falun Gong activists for the incursion, but said the signal was still being traced and offered no hard evidence that the group was behind it. 

Broadcast officials said that sections of early evening news reports on June 23 were replaced by clips of Falun Gong gatherings in China, apparently before the government banned the group in 1999.

The Chinese leadership has arrested and imprisoned hundreds of Falun Gong members during a continuing crackdown that followers say has been extreme in its brutality.

The news conference came a week after about 100 protesters turned up at the commemorative anniversary celebrations of Hong Kong's return to mainland China.

Falun Gong remains legal in Hong Kong and followers said they were worried their situation would worsen during Tung's second term as chief executive - immigration officials prevented more than 100 followers from entering to attend the protests.

episodes.title: Cult spokesman repeats claim that cloned baby born in Israel
episodes.description:
(30 Jan 2003) 

1. Set up of Israeli spokesperson for Raelian religious sect, Kobi Drori
2. SOUNDBITE (Hebrew) Kobi Drori, spokesperson for the Raelians in Israel: 
"The parents got scared after so many efforts were made to bring this child into the world, after ten failed attempts of in-vitro fertilisation. That's why they decided to leave the US and move to another country and it seems that they chose Israel."
3. Cutaway Raelian symbol worn as necklace
4. SOUNDBITE (Hebrew) Kobi Drori, spokesperson for the Raelians in Israel:
"It seems, as has been published, that the parents are Jewish and had no problems getting Israeli citizenship for the child. In no way did they want to give the child American citizenship, in order to prevent the American courts taking the child away from her parents. That's why the Florida court judge decided to dismiss the case against them."
5. Drori walking away

STORYLINE:

An Israeli spokesman for a religious sect that claims to have created the first human clone has confirmed that the child has been brought to Israel.

In December, the company Clonaid announced it had performed the first successful cloning of a human, an infant it called Eve. 

Kobi Drori told APTN on Thursday that he believed the baby girl had been brought into the country legally.

Although Israeli law does not allow cloning, Drori said it did not prevent cloned people from entering the country.

Israeli Justice Ministry officials said they were looking into the matter. 

On Wednesday a Florida judge threw out a petition seeking the appointment of a guardian for the child, after Clonaid chief Brigitte Boisselier announced the the clone was in Israel.

The company has never delivered on a promise to present mother and child to DNA testing. 

The religious sect behind Clonaid, a group called the Raelians, believes life on earth was started by extraterrestrials. 

Clonaid claimed last week that a third cloned child, a boy, had been born in Japan. It said clone No. 2, a girl,
was born to a Dutch lesbian on January 3.

episodes.title: Doomsday cult still in their underground hideout, MP comment
episodes.description:
(19 Nov 2007) 
1. Wide of Nikolskoye village in snow covered valley
2. Wide of the sect's church
3. Close-up of cross
4. Water flowing in snow covered brook
5. Wide of valley, police post in the distance
6. Location of dug-out
7. Wide of officials and journalists in snow
8. Policeman with Russian politician from the Fair Russia Party, Aleksei Mitrofanov
9. Wide of police vehicles
10. SOUNDBITE: (Russian) Aleksei Mitrofanov, Russian politician from the Fair Russia Party
"I would like people to think before taking extraordinary steps I have taken a walk in this village and a bunch of people here live badly, and honestly speaking, there are many who drink a lot and have no work. This doesn't interest anyone. No-one comes here, no officials take an interest. Journalists have only come here because of this case. Those people who are above ground aren't much better than those who are underground."
11. Hole used for ventilation
12. Various of empty hut in village
13. Wide of village
STORYLINE:
Members of a doomsday cult were still holed up in their underground hideout in snowy central Russia on Monday, a few days after Orthodox priests tried to coax them out.
Twenty-nine people, including four children, the youngest 18 months old, retreated to the bunker near the village of Nikolskoye in the Penza region, about 640 kilometres (400 miles) southeast of Moscow, earlier this month and have threatened to blow themselves up if forced to leave.
However, their leader, self-declared prophet Pyotr Kuznetsov, was not amongst them. 
Kuznetsov was charged last week with setting up a religious organisation associated with violence and underwent psychiatric evaluation on Friday.
On Thursday, Russian Orthodox monks tried to make contact with the cult but members refused to speak to them.
Priests went again on Sunday, but the followers refused to listen to their arguments, according to a security official monitoring the crisis.
He refused to be named because he wasn't authorised to speak to reporters.
The followers, reportedly mostly women, vowed to stay in the bunker until doomsday, claiming to have stockpiled 100 gallons of gasoline that they threatened to ignite if officers on guard near the ravine try to force them out.
They remain in written contact with Kuznetsov.
Kuznetsov, a 43-year-old engineer from a devout family, declared himself a prophet several years ago. 
He left his family and the Russian Orthodox Church and established the True Russian Orthodox Church. 
After leaving home, Pyotr Kuznetsov began writing books, borrowing from a mixture of established beliefs, and visited monasteries in Russia and Belarus, recruiting followers, Guseynov said.
He reportedly told followers that in the afterlife they would be judging whether others deserved heaven or hell.
Followers are not allowed to watch television, listen to the radio or handle money, reports say.

episodes.title: Update on cave cult which awaits the end of the world
episodes.description:
(18 Nov 2007) 
1. Wide of ravine
2. Wide of hill, police post in the distance, zoom in to location of dug-out
3. Various of the holes used for ventilation, pan from one hole to the other 
4. Wide of police post 
5. Mid of ventilation hole behind branches (to right of picture) 
6. Wide pan of Nikolskoye Village 
7. Wide of the sect's church 
8. Close-up door to church, cross marked on door with chalk, door opens to show interior
9. Wide pan from one cross to another 
10. Horse in harness
11. Barking dog 
12. SOUNDBITE: (Russian) Nikolai Kuznetsov, cult leader's neighbour:
"He is a very good chap, well bred, not spoiled as in other families. He did not indulge in wine, studied, that's how I knew him."
13. Wide back view of church
14. Close-up of tools
15. SOUNDBITE: (Russian) Nikolai Kuznetsov, cult leader's neighbour:
"What? The end of the world? If we ourselves don't do it, don't blow it up?"
(Question: Why did you not hide there?)
"I have been asking myself why they are doing it and what they want."
(Question: And what do you think of it?)
"What do I think? I think nothing good will come out of it."
16. Various exteriors of church 
17. Wide of houses
STORYLINE:
Priests tried unsuccessfully to coax members of a doomsday cult from their underground hideout in snowy central Russia where they remained barricaded on Sunday.
Twenty-nine people, including four children, the youngest 18 months, retreated to the bunker near the village of Nikolskoye in the Penza region, about 640 kilometres (400 miles) southeast of Moscow, earlier this month and have threatened to blow themselves up if forced to leave.
However, their leader, self-declared prophet Pyotr Kuznetsov, was not among them on Sunday. 
Kuznetsov was charged last week with setting up a religious organisation associated with violence and underwent psychiatric evaluation on Friday.
On Thursday, Russian Orthodox monks tried to make contact with the cult but members refused to speak with them.
Priests went again on Sunday, but the followers refused to listen to their arguments, according to a security official monitoring the crisis.
He refused to be named because he was not authorised to speak to reporters.
Yevgeny Guseynov, a spokesman for the regional government, said officials would try to find experienced negotiators.
The followers, reportedly mostly women, vowed to stay in the bunker until doomsday, claiming to have stockpiled 100 gallons of gasoline that they threatened to ignite if officers on guard near the ravine try to force them out.
They remained in written contact with Kuznetsov.
Kuznetsov, a 43-year-old engineer from a devout family, declared himself a prophet several years ago. 
He left his family and the Russian Orthodox Church, and established the True Russian Orthodox Church. 
"He is a very good chap, well bred, not spoiled as in other families. He did not indulge in wine, studied, that's how I knew him," said Nikolai Kuznetsov, a neighbour of  Pyotr Kuznetsov but no direct relation.
"I think nothing good will come out of it," Nikolai added when asked his opinion on the cult's actions.
After leaving home Pyotr Kuznetsov began writing books, borrowing from a mixture of established beliefs, and visited monasteries in Russia and Belarus, recruiting followers, Guseynov said.
He reportedly told followers that in the afterlife, they would be judging whether others deserved heaven or hell.
Followers were not allowed to watch television, listen to the radio or handle money, reports say.
Anna Vabishchevich said her 41-year-old son, Alexander, his wife and their two teenage daughters were followers.

episodes.title: South Korean fugitive cult leader Jung extradited back to Seoul
episodes.description:
(20 Feb 2008) 
POOL
1. Wide of an aircraft taxing on airport tarmac
2. Zoom in to Jung Myung-seok (wearing a mask) walking down stairs with prosecution officials 
3. Top shot, zoom in to Jung walking towards car and getting in 
4. Cars driving away
AP Television
5. Close-up of electronic arrivals board showing arrival of Jung's plane 
6. Wide of gathered Jesus Morning Star followers and police officers at Incheon International Airport
7. Various of Jesus Morning Star followers
8. SOUNDBITE: (Korean) Bae Jae-yong, follower of Jesus Morning Star: 
"He has never been directly involved with the finances as he manages the congregation, so his embezzlement charge is just a groundless rumor. The rape charge is also a distorted rumor that was made by the people who have slandered him. Everything is different from the truth, and all fundamental truth will be clarified by him at the prosecutor's office." 
9. Various of Jesus Morning Star followers 
10. Tilt-down pan from electronic board to followers 
STORYLINE:
The leader of a homegrown South Korean religious sect was extradited back to Seoul on Wednesday from China on charges of raping female followers.
Jung Myung-seok, the 63-year-old leader of the Jesus Morning Star sect or JMS, was arrested in China in May last year after more than six years on the run. 
South Korean prosecutors had asked China to send him home to face rape charges.
Kim Hye-woong, a Justice Ministry official, said Jung faced the same charges as before.
Local media have reported that Jung raped followers and forced them to have group sex with him, saying God allowed him all women in the world and warning they would find themselves "in great trouble" if they rejected his demands.
South Korean media also reported that Jung had claimed to have received a "special revelation" from God, and that many female members of his cult were ordered to undress for a "health check" and have sex with him to wipe off their sins. 
Jung denies the charges, his followers say.
Bae Jae-yong, one of hundreds of followers who waited for Jung at the airport, called the charges "a distorted rumor that was created by the people who have slandered him."
"Everything is different from the truth, and all fundamental truth will be clarified by him at the prosecutor's office," he said.
Followers were not able to see Jung as prosecutors placed him in a car on the tarmac.
Jung's case became known after Korean television network SBS first carried a report on his alleged wrongdoing in 1999. 
At that time, thousands of followers protested at the TV station over the report.
It is unclear how many followers the sect now has.
Jung is also known by the names of Joshua Jung, Joshua Lee Jung, Joshua Lee, and JMS.

episodes.title: Bond lowered for sect leader accused of sex crimes
episodes.description:
(9 May 2008) SHOTLIST

1. Mid of sign reading (English) Union County Magistrate Court 
2. Wayne Bent getting out of car
3. SOUNDBITE (English) Jeff Bent, Son of Wayne Bent: 
"Today, my father Wayne Bent, also known as Michael Travesser, was formally charged with crimes he did not commit.  He is an innocent man being crucified by those who have an agenda against him."
4. Wayne Bent leaving court and talking to reporters UPSOUND: (English) Journalist: "Mr Bent you were talking a lot about innocence in there. Are you innocent?"
Jeff Bent: "Yes sir"
Journalist: "And tell us, do you think you got a fair shake down today?" 
Journalist: "And Mr Bent are you going to continue not eating today?"
Bent: "For the present time."
Journalist: "Is it a fast or is it a..."
Bent: "It's a fast."
Journalist: "Not a hunger strike?"
Bent: "No."
5. SOUNDBITE (English) Jeff Bent, Son of Wayne Bent:
"In the work God has given my father to do, he has at times, been required by God to come into close physical contact with people.  Sometimes he touches people to heal them of a physical or spiritual problem.  On a few rare occasions, and only at the request of the person who has come to him, he has allowed them to remove their clothing."
6. Cutaway of media
7. SOUNDBITE (English) Jeff Bent, Son of Wayne Bent:
"This case is not about sex as the state would have us believe, it's about removing a cult leader the state wants out of the way.  It is about crucifying someone the public finds offensive."
8. Various of streets of Clayton
9. SOUNDBITE (English) Connie Thelander, Local Resident:
"Those poor children, I just am...  Children, I just worry about the children."
10. SOUNDBITE (English) PJ Fernandez, Local Resident :
"I'm just worried about my kids, you know.  That's why.  It don't bother me any no, it's just awful what he's doing out there.  You know, everybody has their beliefs but I think he's just taking it to a whole other level."
11.SOUNDBITE (English) Connie Thelander, Local Resident:
"Personally, I think they all are more or less brainwashed they don't know...  They have probably a strong belief in what their doing and that's the sad part.  But as far as, you know, from now on, what will happen...  Personally, I wish they would pack up and move."
12. Pull out of streets of Clayton


STORYLINE:

A judge reduced the bond of an apocalyptic-sect leader accused of sex crimes against girls who were part of his church, but she rejected his request on Thursday to be released on his own recognisance.

Union County Magistrate Ilene Taylor cut Wayne Bent's bond from 500 thousand US dollars, to 55 thousand US dollars. 

He was returned to jail, where authorities said he has refused to eat or drink since his arrest on Tuesday.

Bent, who goes by the name of Michael Travesser and claims to be the Messiah, is accused of touching three underage female followers, one of whom was 12, when they lay naked with him in 2006 and 2007.

Bent said he did not have any money to pay for an attorney, so he was assigned a public defender, Sarah Montoya.

Montoya tried to enter a plea of not guilty, but Taylor said the purpose of Bent's first court appearance was to read him his rights and the charges
against him, not to enter a plea.

A preliminary hearing was to be held for Bent within 10 days, unless he posts bond, in which case the hearing would be within 60 days.

Bent, 66, is the leader of The Lord Our Righteousness Church, whose members moved in 2000 to a remote former ranch near the Colorado line that they call Strong City. 










after the hearing.




early 2006.

episodes.title: HONG KONG: FALUN GONG: NEW ANTI CULT LEGISLATION
episodes.description:
(31 Oct 1999) English/Nat

China has passed new anti-cult legislation in an attempt to eradicate the banned Falun Gong movement. 

Their action paves the way for Falun Gong leaders to be given lengthy prison terms and possibly the death penalty.

Police have been ordered to smash all cult activity, and reports from Beijing say they have quelled the week-long series of protests by defiant but peaceful Falun Gong members.

But in Hong Kong, where the spiritual group is still allowed to exist, the group is stepping up its activities to draw attention to the fate of its followers on the mainland.

After Friday's silent demonstration outside the central government offices in Hong Kong, Falun Gong followers chose a Sunday afternoon for another demonstration on Hong Kong's peak, an area popular as a weekend day-out destination.

Members of the banned spiritual group are arrested on the mainland but in Hong Kong they are still free to follow their beliefs and to demonstrate in public.

For six days, they have been maintaining a small vigil outside the offices of the New China News Agency.

But they say they intend to increase the scale and frequency of events like this, designed to increase public awareness of their belief and of the persecution they suffer in mainland China.

Yesterday China's National People's Congress passed a new law that increases the power of the police and the courts to prosecute followers of spiritual beliefs that the Chinese government has dismissed as "cults". 

In passing this law, the National People's Congress exhorted police and the courts to be "on full alert of cult activities and to smash them rigorously."

By tightening the law on cults, the communist government speeded the crackdown toward trials of principal members already in custody. 

But the need for new measures shows how threatened Chinese leaders feel by Falun Gong, the alternatives it offers and how undaunted its followers remain more than three months into a ban on the widely popular group.

Although defiant, members are shocked at the Chinese move to legislate against them.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"I'm shocked, I'm very very shocked, I think all practitioners feel very disappointed with the government. So many people practice Falun Dafa in China and we are all good people, and the government is doing this. And we are very disappointed and shocked and it is time we really need to speak out to the world and tell people what we really are."
SUPER CAPTION: Belinda Pang, Falun Gong Member

The Hong Kong government has not made any indication that it will follow mainland policy. 

As part of the mini-constitution put in place after the 1997 handover, Hong Kong's citizens are guaranteed the same religious freedoms they enjoyed under British rule.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"I'm not worried here because in Hong Kong we have one country, two systems. I trust the government, I trust the system, that we will allow us the freedom of speech, freedom of pursuing our belief, freedom of practising Falun Dafa."
SUPER CAPTION: Belinda Pang, Falun Gong Member

Some Hong Kong Falun Gong followers have claimed that they are being monitored and followed. 

A spokesman said that the number of followers in Hong Kong has dropped by thirty per cent since Beijing outlawed the group on the mainland three months ago.

It is estimated that there are now about five hundred Falun Gong practitioners in Hong Kong. 

The group's faith is a mixture of Buddhism, Taoism, meditation and breathing exercises. 

The cult claims to have one hundred (m) million followers worldwide.

episodes.title: GNS WEEKLY NEWS: CHINA: FALUN GONG
episodes.description:
(7 Nov 1999) Mandarin/Nat

Chinese authorities have stepped up their campaign against the Falun Gong spiritual  movement.

The country's top religious claims the movement will soon be eradicated.

The Chinese government banned the Falun Gong cult in July and has rounded up  dozens of its leaders.

But cult members have continued to defy the ban.

The Chinese government seems determined to eliminate all traces of the Falun Gong  movement.

On Thursday it brought out what it said was evidence supporting its claim that the cult  was dangerous, both to the country and to its own members.

The government's director of religious affairs, Ye Xiaowen, said the group's U-S based  founder, Li Hongzhi, had tricked his (M) millions of followers.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"Li Hongzhi like other cult leaders says that the world will be destroyed and that he can  control the timing of the end of the world. He can help people to go to heaven."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

Ye also said Li had led 14-hundred cult members to their deaths by advising them  against taking medicine when ill.

He added there was no room for such behaviour in modern day China.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"The indulgence of cults is anti-scientific, an insult to civilisation and a trampling of  human rights."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

Journalists were shown a government video which included images of burnt and  mutilated bodies.

It claimed the dead people had been Falun Gong members and that the cult was  responsible for their deaths, although it did not elaborate on how they had died.

Many outside observers believe the government crack down may have more to do with  the threat to its power it perceives the cult poses.

Government agents began infiltrating and investigating Falun Gong after at least 10  thousand of its members surrounded the Chinese leadership's compound in central  Beijing in April, in a day-long protest seeking legal recognition for the movement.

It banned the group three months later.

There are estimated to be up to 70 (M) million Falun Gong practitioners in China.

Ye tried to suggest  anyone expressing support for the cult was hostile to China's  interests.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"I have to point out that Falun Gong has some international support. It's supported by  people with hostile intentions toward China and Chinese people."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

An he openly admitted the government considered the group a threat to the communist  party.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"The threat to people and society is also a threat to the Central Committee of our Party  and to our government."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

The cult continues to protest at what it calls government persecution.

Group members have been holding almost daily gatherings Beijing's Tiananmen square.
