episodes.title: USA: NEW YORK: FALUN GONG GROUP STAGE PROTEST
episodes.description:
(29 Oct 1999) English/Nat

About 100 members of a spiritual sect banned in China have demonstrated outside the U-N headquarters in New York, denouncing Beijing's crackdown on the group.

The protesters denied that the Falun Gong group was "an evil cult" and asked the Chinese government to stop persecuting the group's members.

The protest came as at least 50 followers were arrested in Beijing, bringing to at least  three-thousand the number of people reportedly detained by the Chinese this week.

Members of Falun Gong remain peaceful in the face of adversity. 

But as the Chinese government detains more and more of the group's followers, their voices grow stronger. 

On Friday, practitioners of the spiritual movement, also known as Falun Gong, asked the United Nations, specifically its Secretary General, to intervene in the crisis.

The protesters in New York claimed that the human rights of over 100 (m) million Chinese citizens are at risk because they are not allowed to practice their beliefs.

The Falun Gong sect blends traditional Qigong exercises with more advanced spiritual meditation, 

The demonstrators urged the U-N to pressure China to reverse its policies. 

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"And we hope that the U-N can have a peaceful dialogue with the Chinese government and Mr. Li Hongzhi (leader of Falun Gong movement."
SUPER CAPTION: Sun Yan, Falun Gong practitioner 

Since the movement was banned by China in July, numerous reports of torture and ill-treatment of its followers were received by human rights organisations. 

The Chinese government has also burned the numerous books associated with what it calls an "evil sect".

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
"What our government is doing is really like the Cultural Revolution. It is using propaganda wars to turn down somebody, so I hope such disaster would not happen again."
SUPER CAPTION: Sun Yan, Falun Gong practitioner 

The head of the movement, Li Hongzhi, has not been seen or heard of since he gave a series of interviews in July when the group was banned.

He is reportedly still in the U-S, although spokespeople for the group say his personal safety may be at risk after the Chinese government issued a warrant for his arrest. 

Falun Gong members maintain they are not members of a sect and that they have no political inclinations other than to restore the legality of their movement.

The group's detractors say that Falun Gong is sect-like in that it encourages its members to shun traditional medical help and that they are lead to believe that Li Hongzhi is the reincarnation of Buddha.

episodes.title: HONG KONG: FALUN GONG MEMBERS GATHERING
episodes.description:
(11 Dec 1999) English/Nat

As fellow practitioners continue to be detained and reportedly beaten in mainland China, hundreds of Falun Gong members gathered outside the Hong Kong offices of Beijing's state-run media on Saturday.

Hong Kong devotees joined forces with others from mainland China, Japan, Taiwan, Australia, Canada and Western Europe for a peaceful demonstration, in an attempt to appeal to the Chinese government for greater understanding.

Hong Kong is the only place in China where the sect is legally allowed to practice.

Amid a chorus of gongs and string instruments, about 600 members of a sect banned in China raised their arms and closed their eyes in an 'exercise session' outside the Hong Kong headquarters of China's state-run Xinhua News Agency on Saturday.

This was not a protest, they said, at the largest gathering of Falun Gong members so far in the territory.

Beijing's media has labelled Falun Gong "an evil cult, responsible for malicious fallacies harmful to people's minds and bodies," and mainland authorities have rounded up hundreds if not thousands of the sect's members in China.

The demonstrators tried to give China's state-run Xinhua News Agency an open letter addressed to Chinese President Jiang Zemin, but the doors remained locked.

Nobody came out to receive the letter.

"Can Falun Gong truly scare people like fierce floods and savage beasts?" the letter said. "Does Falun Gong really present a danger to the Communist Party, the state, society and the human race?"

Other Falun Gong practitioners left petitions on the doorstep of the building.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
" My intention of being here is to ask the Chinese government to have an open and peaceful dialogue with practitioners and Mr. Li Hongzhi so that the situation can be resolved peacefully. And less people can get hurt, less people can get tortured. And they can be resolved quicker. "
SUPER CAPTION: Zenon Dolnyckyj, Canadian practitioner 

Police say about 20 officers had been deployed around the sidewalks across Xinhua's offices to monitor the demonstration.

Membership of the sect  has dwindled in Hong Kong since the crackdown earlier this year on the mainland, and practitioners fear that Beijing's control will prevail - despite assurances from Hong Kong leaders that religious freedom will be upheld.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"The kind- hearted people inside the Chinese government will listen to our voice ultimately but we do not expect very immediate effect from the Chinese government."
SUPER CAPTION:  Kan Hung Cheung, Falun Gong Spokesperson

Falun Gong blends slow-motion meditation exercises and ideas from Taoism, Buddhism and Falun Gong's U-S based founder, Li Hongzhi.

Practitioners say Falun Gong promotes health and good citizenship.

episodes.title: HONG KONG: FALUN GONG MEMBERS VOW TO DISOBEY BAN
episodes.description:
(22 Jul 1999) English/Nat

China on Thursday outlawed the Falun Gong sect, saying it regards the meditation  group as a serious threat to  national stability after three days of cult members  protesting across China.

Hours after the ban was announced, some Hong Kong members of Falun Gong were  vowing to keep practicing, despite what they called a puzzling crackdown by Beijing.

About 60 members of the Falun Gong meditation sect assembled in an apartment in  Hong Kong's Kowloon district on Thursday evening, to discuss the day's events.

China banned the popular meditation sect on the mainland on Thursday, after three  days of massive protests, intensifying a crackdown on a group Chinese leaders see as  a serious threat to their rule.

The ban, reported by state media, accused Falun Gong of spreading "superstitious, evil  thinking" to undermine social stability.

But Falun Gong faces no restrictions in Hong Kong, and members can't see why  Beijing had a problem on the mainland.

The Falun Gong adherents blend martial arts with thought from Buddhism and Taoism. 

But China's leaders might see the very size of Falun Gong as a threat.

Its membership exceeds that of China's Communist Party.

But in Hong Kong these Falun Gong practitioners were keen to stress that the sect had  no political agenda.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"Legal and illegal, good and bad are different, we want to be good, and they call it legal  and illegal. It's political, we are not ourselves political, so this is different."
SUPER CAPTION: Albert Kwok, Falun Gong member

He also showed his disbelief at the crackdown.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"I think it is quite unbelievable because what we want is to be a good person. If a good  person is called illegal, there must be something wrong in that place."
SUPER CAPTION: Albert Kwok, Falun Gong member

Many at the Hong Kong meeting sat in a cross-legged yoga position as they chanted  and read aloud from the works of the Falun Gong's founder, Li Hongzhi. 

Li is a former soldier and government clerk in China, who now lives in the United States.

Several Falun Gong people said there are 40 loosely knit branches in Hong Kong, now  part of China but still enjoying a great deal of autonomy as a so-called "Special  Administrative Region."

Some of the members delivered a petition to the Hong Kong offices of China's official  news agency, Xinhua, on Wednesday.

But say Xinhua never responded.

Shortly after speaking to reporters, the members asked to be left alone so they could  continue their chants and discussion privately.

But one member of Falun Gong was willing to talk for longer.

Sophie Xiao has relatives in China who are members of Falun Gong and have been  arrested.

Asked what she thought would happen to them, she said they would be "fine".

She explained that whatever members are told about their beliefs, they still have their  own judgement.

She went on to say she hopes the Chinese authorities change their minds on the  banning.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
"We still would like our government to rethink their decisions over this, you know,  outlaw of Falun Gong, we would ask them to rethink about it."
SUPER CAPTION: Sophie Xiao, member of  Falun Gong

But in case this does not happen Falun Gong clearly does not intend letting China's  latest action pass-by without reacting.

The latest message on their website, on Thursday, says that "Urgent action" is needed  to protect their "principles", and, "Let's have an urgent reaction to protect our  principles!"

episodes.title: CHINA: FALUN GONG CULT MEMBERS DEFY BAN
episodes.description:
(4 Nov 1999) Mandarin/Nat

Chinese authorities have stepped up their campaign against the Falun Gong spiritual movement.

The country's top religious claims the movement will soon be eradicated.

The Chinese government banned the Falun Gong cult in July and has rounded up dozens of its leaders.

But cult members have continued to defy the ban.

The Chinese government seems determined to eliminate all traces of the Falun Gong movement.

On Thursday it brought out what it said was evidence supporting its claim that the cult was dangerous, both to the country and to its own members.

The government's director of religious affairs, Ye Xiaowen, said the group's U-S based founder, Li Hongzhi, had tricked his (M) millions of followers.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"Li Hongzhi like other cult leaders says that the world will be destroyed and that he can control the timing of the end of the world. He can help people to go to heaven."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

Ye also said Li had led 14-hundred cult members to their deaths by advising them against taking medicine when ill.

He added there was no room for such behaviour in modern day China.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"The indulgence of cults is anti-scientific, an insult to civilisation and a trampling of human rights."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

Journalists were shown a government video which included images of burnt and mutilated bodies.

It claimed the dead people had been Falun Gong members and that the cult was responsible for their deaths, although it did not elaborate on how they had died.

Many outside observers believe the government crack down may have more to do with the threat to its power it perceives the cult poses.

Government agents began infiltrating and investigating Falun Gong after at least 10 thousand of its members surrounded the Chinese leadership's compound in central Beijing in April, in a day-long protest seeking legal recognition for the movement.

It banned the group three months later.

There are estimated to be up to 70 (M) million Falun Gong practitioners in China.

Ye tried to suggest  anyone expressing support for the cult was hostile to China's interests.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"I have to point out that Falun Gong has some international support. It's supported by people with hostile intentions toward China and Chinese people."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

An he openly admitted the government considered the group a threat to the communist party.

SOUNDBITE: (Mandarin)
"The threat to people and society is also a threat to the Central Committee of our Party and to our government."
SUPER CAPTION: Ye Xiaowen, Government Religious Affairs Director

The cult continues to protest at what it calls government persecution.

Group members have been holding almost daily gatherings Beijing's Tiananmen square.

episodes.title: 30th anniv of Jonestown massacre when more than 900 died, survivor, file
episodes.description:
(18 Nov 2008) 
FILE: Jonestown compound in Guyana - 18 November, 1978
1. Aerial of the Jonestown compound after hundreds of people died
2. Aerial of bodies seen lying all over the ground
3. Mid of three bodies covered by sheet
4. Mid of dead bodies lying on ground
5. Investigators walking through strewn dead bodies
San Francisco, California - 18 November 2008
6. Journalist Tim Reiterman, survivor of attack at the airport, sitting at his desk:
7. SOUNDBITE: (English) Tim Reiterman, Journalist who covered Jonestown and survivor of airport attack:
"A tremendous wind seemed to come out of nowhere, and there was a torrent. A torrent of rain and the moment was, it was very, very ominous.  In the coming minutes, members of Peoples Temple gathered around the pavilion, and surrounded us and where we were and all eyes were on Jones, looking for visible cues, some sort of leadership or guidance about what was going to happen next.  I think he knew what was going to happen next."
FILE: Jonestown compound in Guyana - 18 November, 1978
8. Mid of dead bodies on ground outside, one with an arm around another
9. Dead bodies on ground in building 
10. Man sifting through contents on a table, push in to buckets on table, bodies on ground in background
San Francisco, California - 17 November 2008
11. Jonestown survivor, Yulonda Williams standing in front of her family home, which was used by Jones' church
12. SOUNDBITE: (English) Yulonda Williams, Jonestown survivor:
"He had, in my opinion - and I say this, and I'm compelled to say this - he had 917 chances to stop the annihilation, and yet he continued to witness people dying one by one."
13. Williams walking into family home
14. SOUNDBITE: (English) Yulonda Williams, Jonestown survivor:
"Jim Jones had the ability to be able to reach people on whatever level, and to address the needs and concerns of individuals at any given point in time."
FILE: Location and date unknown 
15. Jim Jones seated in chair with a bird on his lap
FILE: California, exact location and date unknown
16. Various of Jones' church
San Francisco, California - 18 November 2008
17. SOUNDBITE: (English) Tim Reiterman, Journalist who covered Jonestown and survivor of airport attack:
"I spent years trying to understand why and how it happened and I still, many people embrace myths about Jonestown.  One of those myths was that it was a mass suicide. That people willingly stepped forward. Whereas in fact, they were manipulated by Jones at the end. The shooting of Congressman Ryan was used to convince Jones' followers that they had no out, no place to go, that someone was going to come in (go) after them.  And, then he said; 'Let's take the potion.'"
FILE: Location and date unknown
18. Jones petting a dog
FILE: Jonestown compound in Guyana - 18 November, 1978
19. Various aerials of Jonestown compound with hundreds of bodies on ground
STORYLINE:
Thirty-years on, survivors of an epic murder-suicide ritual at a compound of Jim Jones' Peoples Temple in Jonestown, northwestern Guyana, remember the more than 900 people who perished there.
The killing began during a fact-finding mission to Guyana's jungle by United States Congressman Leo Ryan.
The congressman from San Mateo, California, had travelled to Guyana to investigate a remote commune built by Jones' California-based People's Temple.
When Ryan and some church members tried to leave, a team of assassins opened fire.
Ryan was fatally shot as he boarded his plane, making him the first congressman slain while holding office. 
Four others, including three newsmen, were also killed.
